children.title: God, activity of
children.comment: God is not passive or remote from his creation but dynamically involved in all that he has made. In the past, this activity was seen in the history of Israel and in the ministry of Jesus Christ. In the present, God's activity can be seen in the life of believers and of the church.

children.title: God, as judge
children.comment: As a part of his sovereignty and authority, God is executor of his righteousness within the created order. Jesus Christ shares in this ongoing work.

children.title: He presides in the heavenly court
God is judge over the whole of creation
Examples of God acting as judge
His judgment of the earth in sending the flood
His judgment of the rulers of nations
His judgment of his own people
God's character is revealed through his righteous judgments
Jesus Christ continues God's work as judge
God will act as judge on the last day
God, as redeemer
children.comment: God alone has the ability to save his people from slavery and captivity. God's redemptive will and power is demonstrated in his deliverance of Israel from bondage in Egypt, and supremely through the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.

children.title: God as the sole redeemer of Israel
He redeems because of his love
He is able to redeem because of his power
He promises to redeem Israel from Egypt
He redeems Israel in the exodus from Egypt
He redeems Israel from Babylonian exile

primaryrefs.comment: ``Redeemer'' is a characteristic title for God in the second part of Isaiah.  In the context of the exile Isaiah reminds Israel that God would act as redeemer.

children.title: God redeems his people from difficult personal circumstances

seealsos.comment: Abraham was redeemed from the land of idolatry to become God's servant
Job, in the midst of his despair, declares God to be his redeemer
part of the psalmist's prayer for deliverance when confronted by an evil conspiracy
the lamentor recognises personal redemption within the context of national despair

children.title: God redeems his people from the bondage and guilt of sin
Those who remain sinful do not find redemption

seealsos.comment: The request for redemption is made on the basis of uprightness

children.title: God redeems his people from death
Jesus Christ is central to God's redemptive purposes
God will finally redeem all creation at Jesus Christ's second coming
God's redemptive work brings him praise and worship
God, as Saviour
children.comment: God is the only Saviour and deliverer of his people. His work of salvation is inaugurated in the OT, and reaches its climax in the work of Jesus Christ.

children.title: God's deliverance can be worked through a human agent
Examples of God's saving deeds
children.precomment: God delivers his people from Egypt:

secondaryrefs.comment: God delivers Daniel from the lions' den.

children.title: God's acts of deliverance reveal his nature and character

primaryrefs.comment: ``rock'' and ``horn'' symbolise God's strength; they are fequently used to emphasise his ability to save.

children.title: Implications of God's deliverance for believers
God is able to deliver believers from trials and testing
God is able to deliver believers from sin and death

primaryrefs.comment: God delivers both from death owing to adversity and from death that comes about as a result of sin.

children.title: Testimony to God as Saviour and deliverer
God, the Creator
children.comment: God's power is revealed in the initial creation and the continuing sustenance of the universe. Humanity represents the climax of the Creator's purposes.

children.title: God's creative activity demonstrates his uniqueness
God's creative activity implies that he is good
The human race is the apex of God's creation

primaryrefs.comment: Wisdom is personified and is active with the Creator.
God creates out of non-existent material, which emphasises the absolute dependence of all creation upon him.

children.title: The Creator sustains the created order

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew indicates continuous activity.

children.title: The Creator watches over his creation
The creation is a vehicle for God's self-revelation
God renews his creation through redemption

seealsos.comment: The redemption of the physical world must wait until the sons of God are revealed at the end of time

children.title: God renews his new creation of believing people
God will reveal a new universe
God, the provider
children.comment: God supplies the needs of all creation, but gives special care to his own people.

children.title: God is called ``The LORD who provides''

primaryrefs.comment: The name ``Yahweh Yireh'' (or ``Jehovah Jireh'') is from the verb ``to see'', and means ``The LORD foresees'' or ``The LORD will see to it''.

children.title: God provides for the needs of all creation
He provides for the poor and needy
Special instances of God's practical provision
children.precomment: Food and water in the wilderness:

secondaryrefs.comment: Elisha feeds 100 men from 20 barley loaves

children.title: God's special provision for his own people
He provides for their practical needs
He provides for their every need
Examples of God's provision for his people

secondaryrefs.comment: a way of escape from temptation

cschildren.title: God is active by nature

children.title: He actively works out his purposes
His names reflect his activity and involvement in his people's lives

secondaryrefs.comment: ``The LORD is my Banner'': this title emphasises that God is like a warrior who champions his people's cause
``The LORD our Maker'': the Hebrew word used does not refer to original creation but to the way in which God is fashioning a people for himself.

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew for ``word'' can also be translated ``deed'' or ``action''. God's word is not merely a communication of abstract truth but a powerful force active in the world.

cschildren.title: God is active in the creation

children.title: In bringing about changes in the weather
In the stars and other heavenly bodies

cschildren.title: God is active in Israel's history

children.title: In the calling and creation of Israel as a people
In saving and delivering his people

primaryrefs.comment: This verse introduces a psalm which recounts the history of God's dealings with his people.

children.title: In raising up and sending leaders to the people

cschildren.title: God is active in the nations of the world

children.title: Examples of nations through which God acts

cschildren.title: God is active in human life

children.title: He determines the course of human lives
Examples of God's intervention in human lives

cschildren.title: God is active in Jesus Christ's ministry
God is active through the Holy Spirit
God is active in the church

primaryrefs.comment: This verse comes in the context of teaching about the body of Christ and the gifts which the Spirit gives to the church.

children.title: God, as judge
children.comment: As a part of his sovereignty and authority, God is executor of his righteousness within the created order. Jesus Christ shares in this ongoing work.

children.title: He presides in the heavenly court
God is judge over the whole of creation
Examples of God acting as judge
His judgment of the earth in sending the flood
His judgment of the rulers of nations
His judgment of his own people
God's character is revealed through his righteous judgments
Jesus Christ continues God's work as judge
God will act as judge on the last day

children.title: God as the sole redeemer of Israel
He redeems because of his love
He is able to redeem because of his power
He promises to redeem Israel from Egypt
He redeems Israel in the exodus from Egypt
He redeems Israel from Babylonian exile

seealsos.comment: Abraham was redeemed from the land of idolatry to become God's servant

part of the psalmist's prayer for deliverance when confronted by an evil conspiracy
the lamentor recognises personal redemption within the context of national despair

children.title: God redeems his people from the bondage and guilt of sin
Those who remain sinful do not find redemption

seealsos.comment: The request for redemption is made on the basis of uprightness

children.title: God redeems his people from death
Jesus Christ is central to God's redemptive purposes
God will finally redeem all creation at Jesus Christ's second coming
God's redemptive work brings him praise and worship

Examples of God's saving deeds
children.precomment: God delivers his people from Egypt:

secondaryrefs.comment: God delivers Daniel from the lions' den.

children.title: God's acts of deliverance reveal his nature and character

primaryrefs.comment: ``rock'' and ``horn'' symbolise God's strength; they are fequently used to emphasise his ability to save.

God is able to deliver believers from trials and testing
God is able to deliver believers from sin and death

God creates out of non-existent material, which emphasises the absolute dependence of all creation upon him.

children.title: The Creator watches over his creation
The creation is a vehicle for God's self-revelation

seealsos.comment: The redemption of the physical world must wait until the sons of God are revealed at the end of time

children.title: God renews his new creation of believing people
God will reveal a new universe

children.comment: God supplies the needs of all creation, but gives special care to his own people.

children.title: God is called ``The LORD who provides''

primaryrefs.comment: The name ``Yahweh Yireh'' (or ``Jehovah Jireh'') is from the verb ``to see'', and means ``The LORD foresees'' or ``The LORD will see to it''.

children.title: God provides for the needs of all creation
He provides for the poor and needy
Special instances of God's practical provision
children.precomment: Food and water in the wilderness:

secondaryrefs.comment: Elisha feeds 100 men from 20 barley loaves

children.title: God's special provision for his own people
He provides for their practical needs
He provides for their every need
Examples of God's provision for his people

secondaryrefs.comment: a way of escape from temptation

children.title: blessing
children.comment: Spiritual and material benefits given by God to be enjoyed. Blessing the name of God is also the appropriate response of believers to all that God has done for them.

cschildren.title: God is the source of all blessing

children.title: At creation he blessed humans with fertility and authority over the earth

cschildren.title: The disobedience of Adam and Eve caused God to remove his blessing

children.title: After the flood God renewed his promise of blessing to Noah

cschildren.title: The blessings promised to Abraham

children.title: The blessings included descendants and nationhood

cschildren.title: The promises of blessing to Abraham were fulfilled in Jesus Christ
Blessings promised to Israel

children.title: Blessings of good health and long life
Blessings of peace and victory over enemies
The promise of being blessed by future restoration

cschildren.title: The conditions of God's blessings

children.title: Fear of the Lord brings blessing
Obedience to the Lord brings blessing

cschildren.title: To bless God is to worship and adore him
People may bless one another in the name of the Lord

primaryrefs.comment: There is a close link between blessing and prayer.

children.title: consistency
children.comment: God's nature, plans and purpose do not change. The same consistent plan of salvation can be seen throughout the OT and NT, culminating in Jesus Christ who is ``the same yesterday and today and for ever''. Believers are also called to show the same consistency in their faith and witness.

cschildren.title: God's nature is consistent and unchanging
God's plans and purpose are consistent and unchanging
God's plan of salvation is consistent
Believers are to live lives consistent with their profession of faith

children.title: covenant
children.comment: God's commitment to, and requirement of, his people expressed in promise, law, judgment, faithfulness and mercy.  Also used of commitment within human relationships based upon agreements.

children.title: covenants, nature of
children.comment: A solemn agreement or promise, sometimes confirmed by sacrifice or by sharing in a meal, by which two or more parties commit themselves to the rights and responsibilities demanded by their relationship and their agreed course of action, and accept the serious consequences of breaking faith.

children.title: The relationship between king and people
Terms for peace granted to a weaker party
A mutual commitment to peaceful relations
An agreement on a common course of action
The relationship between husband and wife

secondaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew expression for making a covenant means, literally, ``to cut a covenant''. This may refer to the solemn practice, described here, of cutting an animal in half and walking between its pieces
Sacrifice is an important part in sealing covenants made by God.

children.title: Covenant obligations are watched over by God
The consequences of breaking covenant faith
Covenants with other nations are forbidden
Covenants with other nations lead to a commitment to foreign gods
Covenants with other nations lead to a denial of faith in God
covenant, God's with Noah
children.comment: God's confirmation of, and commitment to maintain, his relationship with the natural order- implicit in the act of creation- whereby he promised never again to destroy the earth with a flood. This divine pledge, given unconditionally to Noah and to every living creature on earth, was accompanied by the sign of the rainbow.

children.title: God's promise of salvation to Noah and his family
God's promise never again to destroy the earth with a flood
God's relationship with every living creature
God's relationship with the natural order

primaryrefs.comment: God's relationship with the created order is here expressed as a covenant. It is probable that this is a reference to the Noahic covenant through which the implicit relationship between Creator and creation was confirmed.

The reference here is to the Noahic covenant. Though this covenant was unconditional, the prohibition of bloodshed--often described as bringing pollution to the land--was associated with it. There may be, also, a wider reference to the effects of mankind's disregard for the norms laid down at creation.

children.title: covenant, God's with Abraham
children.comment: God's gracious promise made to Abraham, and repeated to his descendants, to bless both them and, through them, the whole world. In response God calls for faithful obedience, expressed particularly in the outward sign of circumcision.

children.title: The covenant is based upon God's gracious promise
The covenant was confirmed by sacrifice
The covenant was given in perpetuity
God promised the land of Canaan
God promised that Abraham would be the father of a nation

seealsos.comment: The change of name from Abram to Abraham is a sign of God's covenant with him

children.title: God promised a relationship with himself

primaryrefs.comment: Circumcision is the sign of Abraham's commitment to God's covenant with him

seealsos.comment: by contrast, the consequences of disobedience

children.title: God shows compassion for his people
The covenant continued through Isaac, not Ishmael
The covenant confirmed through Abraham, Isaac and Jacob

seealsos.comment: Isaac

children.title: The people of Israel are heirs to the covenant
All nations will be blessed through Abraham
covenant, God's at Sinai
children.comment: God's faithful commitment, made in pursuance of his promises to Abraham, to acknowledge the newly-redeemed Israel as his own special people. Israel's required response to the grace of God in election was to be holiness and obedience to the law.

children.title: The covenant fulfilled God's promises to Abraham
The covenant followed Israel's redemption from slavery

primaryrefs.comment: God's covenant at Sinai was made in the context of his historical acts of deliverance. Covenants (``treaties'') between a supreme (suzerain) overlord and a subordinate ruler (vassal) are well known in ancient Near Eastern writings.  They are not ``agreements'' but ``requirements''.

children.title: The covenant was mediated through Moses
The covenant was accompanied by signs of God's presence

secondaryrefs.comment: This pattern of blessings and curses is also a feature of Near Eastern political treaties.

primaryrefs.comment: Israel has been made holy through her election as the covenant people of God. The ensuing call for holiness is a call to work out the implications of that relationship and to live in accordance with its demands

children.title: The consequences of breaking the covenant

primaryrefs.comment: ``love'' translates the Hebrew word ``hesed'', which here expresses God's loyalty and faithful commitment to his covenant people.
God's faithfulness to the covenant at Sinai will result in a new covenant that will never come to an end.

children.title: covenant, God's with Israel's priests
children.comment: God's promise to the Levites, and to the family of Phinehas in particular, to maintain those who serve him faithfully in a lasting priesthood.

primaryrefs.comment: Phinehas was the grandson of Aaron. God's pledge of ``a lasting priesthood'', granted to him as a result of his zeal, probably means that the high priesthood would remain in his family.

This covenant confirms the privileges and responsibilities of Aaron and his fellow Levites who have been called to Israel's priesthood. The reference to ``salt'' may underline the permanent nature of the covenant. God's covenant with David is also described as a ``covenant of salt''.

children.title: The Levites' portion is the LORD

primaryrefs.comment: By their unfaithfulness, Judah's priests have forfeited the blessings of God's promise to Levi.

children.title: covenant, God's with David
children.comment: God's promise to establish David and his descendants on Israel's throne for ever. It provided Israel with a basis for the hope of deliverance and restoration, and became a focus for the Messianic expectation which was fulfilled, ultimately, in Jesus Christ.

children.title: God's promise to establish David's line
God's covenant is inherited through obedience

primaryrefs.comment: Though God's promise to maintain David's throne is unbreakable, individual descendants must continue to be faithful if they are to inherit the blessings promised to David.

children.title: God's covenant blessings are forfeited through disobedience

primaryrefs.comment: Failure to remain faithful to God brings judgment on the royal house and the people.

children.title: God's promise is fulfilled by grace

primaryrefs.comment: Though particular kings may suffer God's anger because of their sin, God's faithfulness to the house of David as a whole, and thus to the nation of Israel, will continue.

children.title: The Davidic covenant as a basis for hope

primaryrefs.comment: God's Name signifies his presence. God's choice of David was closely related to his choice of Jerusalem, the city established by David, as the place where the divine presence symbolised in the temple and the ark of the covenant was to be found.

children.title: God's promise to restore David's house
Hopes expressed in the Davidic covenant are focused in the Messiah
The Messiah fulfils the Davidic hope
God's promise to David fulfilled in Jesus Christ
covenant, the new
children.comment: The fulfilment of God's purposes of salvation expressed in the covenants of the OT, mediated by Jesus Christ and sealed in his blood. It is a covenant of grace, the benefits of which include forgiveness, a renewed relationship with God and, through the Holy Spirit, an inward transformation that enables obedience to its demands and so ensures that it will not again be broken.

primaryref.comment: The ``new'' covenant is contrasted with the covenant made at Sinai which is sometimes referred to as the ``old'' or ``first'' covenant.

children.title: The new covenant fulfils the OT covenants
Jesus Christ, the mediator of the new covenant
The new covenant fulfilled in the Messiah
The new covenant effected through Jesus Christ's death
The new covenant sealed in Jesus Christ's blood

seealsos.comment: Blood was an important element in sealing the Sinaitic covenant

children.title: The ministry of the Holy Spirit
The superior blessings of the new covenant

primaryrefs.comment: The blood of Abel cried out to God for justice and retribution; the blood of Jesus Christ, shed to seal the new covenant, cries out for mercy and forgiveness.

children.title: An inward enabling to obey God's laws

primaryrefs.comment: The old covenant was broken because its demands were not met. Under the new covenant the requirements of obedience are not abolished, but in writing his laws on human hearts, God gives the ability to meet the covenant demands.

``peace'' refers to spiritual and material well-being; real peace is possible only for those in a right relationship with God. The formula ``I will be their God, and they will be my people'' is associated also with the Abrahamic and especially the Sinaitic covenants.

children.title: covenants, nature of
children.comment: A solemn agreement or promise, sometimes confirmed by sacrifice or by sharing in a meal, by which two or more parties commit themselves to the rights and responsibilities demanded by their relationship and their agreed course of action, and accept the serious consequences of breaking faith.

children.title: The relationship between king and people

A mutual commitment to peaceful relations
An agreement on a common course of action
The relationship between husband and wife

secondaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew expression for making a covenant means, literally, ``to cut a covenant''. This may refer to the solemn practice, described here, of cutting an animal in half and walking between its pieces
Sacrifice is an important part in sealing covenants made by God.

Jesus Christ, the mediator of the new covenant
The new covenant fulfilled in the Messiah
The new covenant effected through Jesus Christ's death
The new covenant sealed in Jesus Christ's blood

children.title: providence
children.comment: The continuing and often unseen activity of God in sustaining his universe, providing for the needs of every creature, and preparing for the completion of his eternal purposes.

cschildren.title: God's general providence

primaryrefs.comment: A promise given by God to all peoples.

children.title: All life is dependent on God
God provides for the created world

cschildren.title: God's providence through miraculous means

primaryrefs.comment: God's regular activity in providing for human beings is regarded as being miraculous in just the same way as special demonstrations of his power.

cschildren.title: God's providence in human history

children.title: God's providential actions on behalf of individuals
God's saving purposes fulfilled through providence

cschildren.title: God's providence prepares for the completion of his ultimate purpose

children.title: God is forming a people for himself
God will bring all things under Jesus Christ's authority
God will complete his purpose for creation
God directs all things for his glory
